displayed_text: Patient: Um. Doctor: So that’s what D___ and I will work on. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. So I’ll to go - Doctor: Well then let me; I think she’s out here but I know she will have been in touch with you, but I think she wanted me to clear you today to say hey, that she’s still a candidate because his blood tests have improved and acts with – PSA isn’t bad. Okay. Uh are there questions that you guys have? So we talked about diet; we talked about Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But right now they’re going to spend a little bit more time seeing if the trial makes sense for you – Patient: Right. Doctor: and go through that. Family Member: So tomorrow at ten o’clock even if he has, he’s going to see the urologist, should we send you or will you be in touch with them or how? Doctor: We’ve been getting the notes from whoever you see. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Oh okay.

Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. You know, we’re just checking it more often. Patient: Well, I understand that, but what does that mean to the aggressiveness of the cancer? Does it - Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I mean my sense is that people who, let’s - I don’t have prostate cancer that I know of right now - but, if my PSA was going up and I don’t have the diagnosis, it sort of tells me if it’s going up that fast that I’m more likely when I put a needle in it to find bad cancer. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? Doctor: Yeah, we wanna know where you are as we get started. Patient: And that’s understandable. Doctor: It’s your turn. I want you to do that for me.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Four hundred cubic centimeters or better, Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: but not greater than six hundred. Doctor: Okay good. Family Member: And we … Doctor: And until last time your PSA was coming down. Today’s I don’t know Family Member: Okay. Doctor: if it’s back yet. But everything else, the hemoglobin got slightly better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It went from ten point five to eleven point three. All of that, everything is improving in the right direction. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.10 or more times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::10 or more times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind::: strongly disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or in your case, you haven’t really been on a full dose, and you’ve had these interruptions where you’ve been, you know, totally off of it for three weeks, you know? And now for another two weeks. So. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: So when he comes back on September fifth, the two-hundred milligrams will be here, so he can take it with him that day? Doctor: Yes. That’s the plan. Provided that the hemoglobin is sufficient. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens? Doctor: Uh, I mean, I’ll have to look at the protocol to see, you know, what the rules are about how long the drug can be delayed. But one option would be to call it quits at that point in time and talk about additional therapies, new therapies. The second option would be to keep him off the drug for the maximum amount of time before the study, you know, would kick him out, and then to hope and pray and, and maybe even give another transfusion to make the hemoglobin. If you’re trying that hard to make the hemoglobin not drop, it probably means that it’s not in the best interest of the patient to stay on the study. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So let’s cross that bridge if we get to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, but it will not be a very good sign if despite coming off the drug and the transfusion, the hemoglobin still drops. So after that point, we have a more detailed discussion about alternative options. Patient: Yes.

Patient: Yeah… Doctor: And it can help with any reactions that uh from the chemo too. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So okay. (whispering inaudibly to herself) Patient: No. Doctor: I’ll send it right here? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, cool. Alright so next time I see you will be on the twenty eighth. His PSA wasn’t bad was it? Healthcare Professional: Down, down from so… Doctor: Just slightly down. Healthcare Professional: So slightly down. Doctor: Okay, it’s heading in the right direction. Patient: Oh, okay.

Patient: Start chemo or… Doctor: Yes xxx]. Patient: They don’t do um radiation to the lymph nodes. Doctor: They could, but you know the problem is… Patient: It spreads. Doctor: xxx] right. Yeah. Yeah, it’s not one lymph node that’s remaining. Patient: Right. Doctor: I would rather do the chemotherapy to get things in check, then if there’s one or two resistant spots to the SBRT you know the very closely blind radiation to that. Patient: Right. Family Member: So is there a specific chemotherapy that you would use or do you have an option for… Doctor: No I think then you can get it xxx]. Patient: xxx]. Doctor: Yeah I wouldn’t do it, I would just call Dr. C___.

Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get -- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: a second line hormone versus a second line hormone plus this new PARP drug versus this PARP drug. So, Patient: But, that will be a decision we will make together. Doctor: Yeah, and that’s a coin flip between all those three. Um. That’s kind of a random trial. So, we can talk about that. Um. The immune therapy story is an earlier - it’s still in it’s earlier phases, but people are starting to think, if you have these mutations, you’re making abnormal things on the - in the cell, and that might – and that’s what kind of gets the immune system excited, something that looks weird. And, maybe you would respond better – ‘cuz right now when we give these new immune drugs, they work really well for some cancers Kidney cancer, melanoma, lung cancer. They don’t work very well for prostate cancer in just the general population. So, we’re trying to --- we think they’re good drugs, but we’re trying to figure out what’s the best way to use those. Patient: They might be usable with somebody with the genetic mutation. Doctor: Right. That’s what they’re – we have some kind of preliminary evidence, that’s true. No one’s done a huge study yet to, to prove that. What we were – I told you about this study we’re trying to do which is, we had two men who got one of our testosterone studies, responded, stayed on the drug for about a year, came off the drug, got some other things, and then got an immune therapy trial, with the expectation that the, uh, the immune therapy doesn’t work really well. But, both of those guys had unbelievable response; a ninety-nine percent drop in their PSA, disease disappeared. So, we’re not exactly sure, but what they both had in common was that they got testosterone. So, our, our, one of our trials is looking at that combination. Does the testosterone change the cell surface or whatever? So, we can talk about that, too, but

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: “Hello, I’m Mr. P___ I'm on two of Xtandi”. Patient: Yes. Doctor: PSA is starting to do this, uh-oh, we're kind of worried. So, sometimes the cancer gets smart. And now we say look, maybe there's a way to kind of flap that, see if we can get it to work again, because it did work for a while, which was good. So this pill going right along, we want to add a second pill. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: This study is to add a second pill, different pathway, to say hey, I'm gonna see if I add the second guy whether both together will make your PSA drop. But of course, to make things complicated, the second pill, they want to do stuff too. So they're going to have two groups. So if you're in the first group, you keep going on your Xtandi, and you get the second pill at a particular dose, no problem. Then W____ is on the same study, he's on Xtandi two pills a day. And I give him also the second pill at the same dose. Nobody's placebo-ing, you're now on two potentially active medicines, okay. But to make the study even more interesting, what they're doing is, if you are doing okay, on those two doses, they're going to give you an extra, you know, like 40 milligrams every month to see if they can increase that dose to get better mileage on this activity. But W____ is going to also get a matching pill. But his is not an active 40 milligrams, he just gets the sugar version of the 40 milligrams. Patient: Okay.

Patient: So. Doctor: Exactly. So with your permission we’d like to have S____ - Patient: Mmm. Doctor: - the research nurse come talk to you about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then you know… Patient: Go from there? Doctor: Yeah. We’re still very early on in the process so. Patient: Yeah, that’s fine. I’d just as soon they not come back. Doctor: Yeah and you’re not obligated… Patient: And my wife’s gone through radiation – Doctor: Sure.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the typical you don’t want to get past fifteen hundred a day. Family Member: Yeah they were saying that was too much. Doctor: For some reason that was the top – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - but yeah so no, no. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: For a while actually that was explored as a treatment against prostate cancer – Family Member: Oh. Doctor: - to give mega doses and I mean grams and grams of calcium. Patient: Didn’t work. Doctor: No it was worse. Laughs]]

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it just seems like when we give someone on hormone treatment, two hormone suppressions, it sort of falls off the table, and you, it just magnifies all those symptoms. Not in everybody, but usually I see it more in younger guys like you than I do in, you know, much older guys. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, but I think that would be the easiest thing to do. It’s a pill you take every day. I have a range of responses. I would say, I have a subset of men who respond really well for a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Often, you know, a couple of years. I have another group that respond really well, but it’s not very long lived, maybe a couple of months, six months. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We might find two, three spots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Perhaps lymph nodes, which could be hidden or camouflaged with a conventional CT scan. But everything up to three we will be able to do stereotactic radiation for each of the three metastases. Because more than three then we feel it’s beyond the scope of this trial, it also becomes um less feasible and less practical to target five, six, seven spots. Patient: So at the beginning of the trial you’ll do that scan and that will determine whether I’ll stay in the trial if it’s three or less? Doctor: I believe that the PSMA Pet scan is optional. It’s something that they will discuss with you- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and you may opt out. For example, if you had say I just want to focus on treating that area let’s just do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: now one of the things that about the trial is that it’s randomized. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: What does a randomized trial mean and in this particular case what are people are being randomized too. Randomized means that a computer and then essentially flips a coin and is random, very random in group A and group B of the clinical trial.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So in other words invisible and resistant to hormone therapy, and then we basically do the screening procedures and if you pass the screening then we enroll you in the trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But again, I didn’t want to go into a huge amount of detail because it’s a little bit premature. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it would require also that you go back on the Lupron, which I’m not sure that you would want to do that. So just Patient: Yeah, but if needs be, we can do it, we can do it. There’s another drug that we were on, too, besides Lupron. Doctor: It’s called Zytiga, also known as Abiraterone. Patient: It’s Zytiga. Right. Zytiga. Doctor: And one of the things that you and I have discussed before, and that this might be true especially if you don’t participate in the trial, would be you know could we start the Zytiga without the Lupron. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, in other words, could we have your oral therapy with the absence of or without the Lupron?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, even though some of these things sound cool, I don’t really have a good sense of, you know. So I’d, I’d like to choose either a trial with a hormone drug or just do the hormone drug, uh, as the next step. Patient: Are you satisfied with that we go to? Family Member: Um hum. Patient: I am if you are too?. Family Member: Do you want to do the one, have him go to that one that has, uh, Xtandi and the other one that-? Doctor: The Zytiga or the, no, you mean the trial? Family Member: The trial, yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. I’ll, I’ll clarify that today. Okay? As soon as we’re done. Uh, there’s two different groups I’ve got to talk to, uh, about that. Uh, then I will, uh, I’ll get that information to you as soon as I have it. And if I don’t- Family Member: But one, one of them you said that he’d get both drugs. So he’d probably want to do that one, I guess. Because one you get one and the other one you’re going to get both. You just get the- Patient: You talking about the one with the prednisone? Family Member: No.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: They’ve had Radium. You’ve got Abiraterone. You’ve got Enzalutamide. So, we would look at possibly chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, off, uh, clinical studies, chemotherapy would be, uh, the reasonable next step --- Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve got Taxotere, uh, would be what we would use. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have a number of clinical studies uh, that, uh, are in various per deviations of what we could do. Um. So, we || um, have a study of chemotherapy. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Plus vitamin C. That was data that suggest that vitamin C may reduce the side effects from the chemotherapy, may enhance its activity. We don’t know that. That’s a research question. And, so, um then, you are going to go on chemotherapy and are willing to participate, get randomized to get the vitamin C or a dummy infusion. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. That is cumbersome for someone like you. Uh, you’d have to come in at least twice a week to get the vitamin C. Patient: Mm, hmm.
